Hi Sean, 
On the Knowledge Network there are a number of resources that can help you think of new ways to attract potential employees, especially women and minorities. 

Fostering Advancement for Women and Minorities. 
icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/7026
-Appendix C. The City of San Jose's Public Sector Career Initiative
http://bookstore.icma.org/FreeDocs/CasefromBenestIQReport.pdf
-Recruiting the Next Generation of Firefighters http://icma.org/en/results/public_safety_management/news/Article/103940/Recruiting_the_Next_Generation_of_Firefighters
-How Human Resources can be a Strategic Partner http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9001/public/pmplus1.cfm?title=Get%20Up%2C%20Get%20Out%2C%20Get%20On%20It%3A%20How%20Human%20Resources%20Can%20Become%20a%20Strategic%20Partner&subtitle=&author=Patrick%20Ibarra

I hope you find these resources useful and that when you create your strategy you post a case study of it on the Knowledge Network so we can keep spreading innovative ideas. 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

author: Sean Reeves
text: Our organization is looking for new and innovative ways to recruit more women and minorities into our workforce. We currently advertise on television, radio, the internet, and even attend local job fairs. Our pay and benefits are comparable to neighboring jurisdictions, yet we are not attracting the diverse applicant pool that we are looking for. What advice can you offer on how to successfully diversify? Thanks in advance!
title: Recruiting a Diversified Work Force
